text: the ritual begins with the opening of a
crib a small dark musty room it becomes
crowded past people bump up against
corpses a single candle is lit family
elders attempt to be sure whose room
among the dead
rape or not is the dead are carried into
the daylight one by one every society
has its customs regarding the dead an
interplay between those who are and
those who were in the central highlands
of Madagascar the ancestors are taken
from their tombs and lifted onto the
shoulders of the living who then dance
with the bones the ceremony is called a
fama daeun tears are discouraged this is
a joyous time for family the shrouded
bodies are sometimes sprayed with
perfume are splashed with sparkling wine
she Calloway M&D the reason we do for my
DNA is to honor the dead and to show her
love he helps the family who's left
behind to remember their ancestors
usually a family holds a fama d and only
once every 5 or 7 years hundreds of
guests are sometimes invited and they
must all be fed usually meat and rice
accompanied by urine drama
he's and ozone in a NASA future
generations will keep doing this I have
a son when he grows up he will have
children after I am gone he will
continue the tradition and he will go on
and on the family will help each other
keep the tradition alive
many Malagasy believe the boundary
between life and death is not
impermeable that the spirit of their
ancestors somehow passes back and forth
to them the fama Dean is a time to
inform the deceased of the latest family
news and ask them for blessings and
guidance before the dead are returned to
the tomb they're carefully rewrap the
new shroud going over the old one family
members run their hands over the outline
of the skeleton there's a time when
elders tell young children about each
ancestor and why it is so important that
these forebears be remembered that these
debt never become lost in the world for
the new york times this is barry barrack
